results.title: ‘Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery’ Review: Another Clue for You All
results.abstract: Daniel Craig returns as the world’s greatest detective, facing down a blue-chip cast of possible murderers in Rian Johnson’s new whodunit.
des_facet: Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Daniel Craig returns as the detective Benoit Blanc in “Glass Onion,” Rian Johnson’s sequel to his hit murder mystery, “Knives Out.”

results.title: ‘All the Beauty and the Bloodshed’ Review: Nan Goldin’s Art and Activism
results.abstract: A new documentary focuses on the photographer’s struggle with OxyContin and her protest against the art establishment that took money from its makers.
des_facet: All the Beauty and the Bloodshed (Movie)

multimedia.caption: “Nan in the bathroom with roommate, Boston,” a photograph by Nan Goldin, featured in Laura Poitras’s new documentary “All the Beauty and the Bloodshed.”

results.title: ‘White Noise’ Review: Toxic Events, Airborne and Domestic
results.abstract: Noah Baumbach’s adaptation of the Don DeLillo novel is a campus comedy, a domestic drama and an allegory of contemporary American life.

multimedia.caption: Adam Driver, center, plays Jack Gladney, an academic whose blended family includes his wife, Babette (Greta Gerwig, left), and her daughter, Denise (Raffey Cassidy, foreground right).

results.title: ‘Devotion’ Review: An Airman in Reflection
results.abstract: Jonathan Majors stars as the U.S. Navy’s first Black aviator in this drama from J.D. Dillard.

results.title: Hail to the Queen: Angela Bassett on ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’
results.abstract: The veteran star of “What’s Love Got to Do With It” and “Waiting to Exhale” tried to talk the director, Ryan Coogler, out of a plot twist in the Marvel sequel.

multimedia.caption: “I don’t know, as an actor, what comic-book acting might look like,” said Angela Bassett, adding, “We treat it like life, like it’s happening.”
“I don’t know, as an actor, what comic-book acting might look like,” said Angela Bassett, adding, “We treat it like life, like it’s happening.”

results.title: Jeremy Pope Is Telling Himself ‘Yes’
results.abstract: As the Tony-nominated actor segues to the big screen in the gay military drama “The Inspection,” he reflects on years of shame and learning to accept himself.

multimedia.caption: Pope said the tan suit informed his energy, “like, ‘You’re going to be strong, you’re going to be swag, you’re going to be sexy, and it’s OK for you to be that version of yourself today.’”
multimedia.copyright: Erik Carter for The New York Times

results.title: How Noah Baumbach Made ‘White Noise’ a Disaster Movie for Our Moment
results.abstract: When the world shut down in 2020, the filmmaker found solace in Don DeLillo’s supposedly unadaptable novel — and turned it into a film that speaks to our deepest fears.

multimedia.copyright: Sharif Hamza for The New York Times

results.title: This Mars Documentary Required Many Sols
results.abstract: “Good Night Oppy” chronicles the work and passion of the scientists who shepherded the Mars rover program.

results.title: Irene Cara, ‘Fame’ and ‘Flashdance’ Singer, Dies at 63
results.abstract: Ms. Cara was a child star from the Bronx who gained fame in the 1980s as a singer of pop anthems and as the star of the movie “Fame.”
results.byline: By Alex Traub and Amanda Holpuch

multimedia.caption: Irene Cara as Coco Hernandez performing in a scene from the 1980 movie “Fame.” A former child actor, dancer and singer, she was the voice behind two of the biggest movie theme songs of the 1980s.
Irene Cara as Coco Hernandez performing in a scene from the 1980 movie “Fame.” A former child actor, dancer and singer, she was the voice behind two of the biggest movie theme songs of the 1980s.

results.title: How ‘Black Panther’ Builds Complex Characters From the Politics of Colonization
results.abstract: In the original and in “Wakanda Forever,” heroes and villains are deeply layered, reflecting real-life issues facing people of color around the world.

results.title: Jean-Marie Straub, Uncompromising Filmmaker, Is Dead at 89
results.abstract: Emerging from the French New Wave, driven by artistic purity, he and his wife and directing partner, Danièle Huillet, didn’t care if audiences walked out on their films.

multimedia.caption: Jean-Marie Straub in 1984. He emerged in the 1950s from the same circle of revolutionary French filmmakers as Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, a friend and neighbor.
Jean-Marie Straub in 1984. He emerged in the 1950s from the same circle of revolutionary French filmmakers as Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, a friend and neighbor.
Jean-Marie Straub in 1984. He emerged in the 1950s from the same circle of revolutionary French filmmakers as Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard, a friend and neighbor.

results.title: Lars von Trier Had the Key to the End of ‘The Kingdom’ All Along
results.abstract: As he grapples with Parkinson’s and considers what’s next, the director continues to provoke in “The Kingdom Exodus,” the final season of his haunted-hospital drama.

multimedia.caption: Lars von Trier during production of “The Kingdom Exodus.” He learned he has Parkinson’s while shooting was underway and has since said he is taking a break from filmmaking.
Lars von Trier during production of “The Kingdom Exodus.” He learned he has Parkinson’s while shooting was underway and has since said he is taking a break from filmmaking.

results.title: The Importance of ‘Mr. Baseball’
results.abstract: Thirty years ago, a Tom Selleck comedy introduced Americans to Japanese baseball. It remains a go-to resource for foreign players.

results.title: ‘The Noel Diary’ Review: Revelations on a Cold Winter’s Night
results.abstract: Justin Hartley (“This Is Us”) is no stranger to the themes in this holiday romance, while Barrett Doss (“Station 19”) brings nuanced comedic timing and charm.

results.title: Buffy Sainte-Marie Broke Boundaries in Folk. A Documentary Tells Her Story.
results.abstract: She brought attention to Indigenous issues in her music, and was the first Indigenous person to win an Oscar. “Buffy Sainte-Marie: Carry It On” makes the case for her continued importance.

multimedia.caption: “It wasn’t about careerism at all,” Buffy Sainte-Marie said. “I wanted to write songs that would last for generations.”

results.title: ‘She Said’ Filmmakers and Weinstein Victims: An Emotional Collaboration
results.abstract: Though the drama avoids showing assaults or even much of the producer, a survivor likened reliving the experience to “watching your own car crash.”
